column4: hey all, I'm looking to replace windows vista on a friend's laptop with Ubuntu, hwo can I resize the existing NTFS partition to make way for an ext3 (I should still pick ext3, right?!) partition?
(this is all running off a live cd)
the installer should be able to do it for you, otherwise use GPARTED.  MAKE. BACKUPS. FIRST.
I have free reign to destroy the data, but they'd prefer if it survived ;-)
during the partitioning step it should offer.  or you can pick "manual"
I'd go with gparted then.  got another blank CD/flash drive?
also, windows MUST have been shut down properly to repartition.
personally, I'd worry about getting windows un-broken first.
fix the virus-ridden windows, then install ubuntu.
er.... my question was: if linux had mounted the ntfs partition and not closed in cleanly, then what would I do?
yeah, I know I can force mount it, but that doesn't help solve the problem... how do I get it so that I don't have to force mount it without using windows?
if you force mount it, it marks it as clean.
then your partition is pretty borked.  I'd just reinstall windows, then install linux.  Maybe mount the partition and copy the data off first.
you're likely going to have to reinstall windows ANYHOW if it's all virusey.
